repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Rehabilitation Credit, Recovery
            Program Technical Assistance Project, Public Expenditure
            Support Credit and Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: The
            outcomes of the four projects are satisfactory; the
            sustainability o f all credits is rated as likely; the
            institutional development impact for all four credits is
            rated as substantial; The performance of the International
            Development Association (IDA) for PESC is rated highly
            satisfactory because o f its timely, appropriate and
            effective response to the Kosovo crisis; IDA'S
            performance for ARC, RPTA and SAC is rated satisfactory; the
            Borrower's performance for PESC is rated as highly
            satisfactory because of the government's strong
            commitment and prompt, transparent implementation; and the
            Borrower's performance for ARC, RPTA, and SAC is rated
            satisfactory.  The main lessons from these credits are: 1)
            Small, focused, one-tranche policy projects with realistic
            objectives, supported by technical assistance, may work well
            in transition countries that are politically unstable and
            have low market economy skills. A limited reform agenda is
            easier to implement, especially if parliamentary approval is
            needed for new laws when the political landscape is not
            stable. Reform continuity can be maintained by similar
            policy or investment follow-on projects. 2) The very quick
            preparation and disbursement o f PESC was effective in
            providing development assistance and coordinating
            substantial humanitarian assistance. 3) Disbursement against
            a negative list of imports expedited resource transfer,
            which was appropriate in Albania's circumstances. 4)
            Aid coordination--including the appropriate alignment o f
            government agencies--is critical to ensure appropriate,
            harmonized and effective assistance where many donors are
            involved. 5) Some organizations established for special
            purposes under IDA projects could be transformed into
            private sector commercial entities when their mandate is
            complete. This transition could be an integral part o f that
            organization's strategy.

5002287.owner: Human Development Sector Unit (ECSHD),Private/Financial Sectors Devt (ECSPF),Poverty Reduction/Econ Mngmt (ECSPE)
5002287.trustfund:
TF023249-ALBANIA STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT
            CREDIT - SWISS GRANT,TF023339-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT CREDIT
            FOR ALBANIA FROM NORWAY,TF023516-MULTI-DONOR GRANT FOR THE
            ALBANIA PUBLIC EXPENDITURE TRACKING SURVEYS,TF036256-ALBANIA - STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT CREDIT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. Major lessons indicate that: 1) a reform
            program can be greatly enhanced, when the strategy is to
            combine the project, with follow-up investment operations,
            as well as reducing sustainability risks; 2) an
            inter-ministerial committee, with support from the Prime
            Minister, can become a beneficial tool vs. resistance to
            reform; in this case, the Committee, with ministerial
            intervention, implemented key civil service recruitments,
            confirming that the Government actually was willing to
            enforce the new merit-based civil service law; 3) adjustment
            operations do not need to be all encompassing, free-standing
            operations, rather a structural adjustment operation should
            be seen as an integral element of a broader reform agenda;
            4) a major thrust of the project was strengthening
            institutional capacity, and management of public resources,
            a detailed work program which may set realistic objectives
            to motivate, and stimulate professional viewpoints on
            economic policy, and public sector reform within the
            Government; 5) launching an adjustment operation, in spite
            of crisis conditions, can help preserve a reform agenda, for
            the project provided highly visible support, and increased
            the Bank's credibility, regardless of adverse
            circumstances due to the Kosovo crisis; and, 6) donor
            coordination is critical for success, assuring systematic
            support to the Government.

442075.trustfund:
TF023339-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT CREDIT
            FOR ALBANIA FROM NORWAY,TF023249-ALBANIA STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT
            CREDIT - SWISS GRANT,TF036256-ALBANIA - STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT CREDIT,TF023516-MULTI-DONOR GRANT FOR THE
            ALBANIA PUBLIC EXPENDITURE TRACKING SURVEYS

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC)
            Project seeks to back the government's efforts toward
            the restoration of sustained growth and improved living
            standards through reforms that enhance government
            functioning and also strengthen the environment for more
            efficient private sector development. Governance and
            institutional reform will be the backbone of the reform
            program. The project will aid fiscal adjustment and ensure
            the sustainability of the reform process by strengthening
            the institutional infrastructure needed to improve the
            public sector's capacity to carry out its role
            effectively and efficiently. It will also encourage private
            sector development and improve the efficiency and
            functioning of the banking system. By reducing public sector
            recourse to the banking system, the SAC will allow more
            resources for private sector investment. The project will
            also provide a positive signal to international institutions
            and investors regarding the government's commitment to
            reform. The project risks include: 1) excessive pressure on
            economy and macroeconomic stability as a result of continued
            influx of refugees into Albania; 2) high inflation as a
            result of macroeconomic instability; 3) potential civil
            disorders because of political instability; and 4) program
            implementation delay because of poor coordination among ministries.
